title: Mills and Footbridge, Meaux

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of watercolor with touches of blotting, over traces of graphite, on lightweight, moderately textured, ivory wove paper, laid down on off-white wood-pulp laminate board.

description: Marin made repeated trips to Meaux, an old mill town 25 miles northeast of Paris. Here dabs of diluted pink, red, and yellow suggest the movement of clouds, figures, and wind. Marin painted the sky with long, dry brushstrokes, then defined the clouds, working wet-into-wet by dripping in dilute washes of color that dispersed the pigment and yielded dark, feathered lines. After the washes dried, he punctuated the remaining white of the sky with yellow marks to add brightness. Demonstrating an intuitive understanding of how watercolor behaves, as well as a willingness to experiment with unpredictable results, Marin found such manipulations liberating. This was among the 25 watercolors shown at Stieglitz’s 291 in the spring of 1909, the first time the gallery owner exhibited Marin’s work.
medium_display: Watercolor with touches of blotting, over traces of graphite, on lightweight, moderately textured, ivory wove paper, laid down on off-white wood-pulp laminate board
inscriptions: Signed and datde lower left, in gray watercolor: “Marin 08”; titled left edge, in graphite: “Mills + foot bridge, Meaux”; inscribed verso, center, of secondary support, in graphite: “AS” (underlined); white adhesive label with red variegated border, inscribed, in graphite: “9 / 9”
publication_history: Sheldon Reich, John Marin: A Stylistic Analysis and Catalogue Raisonné (Tucson, 1970), p. 329, no. 08.3 (ill.), as "Bridge and Buildings".
exhibition_history:
New York, Photo-Secession Galleries, "Exhibition of Sketches in Oil by Alfred Maurer, of Paris and New York; and Water-colors by John Marin, of Paris and New York," Mar. 30-Apr. 17, 1909, cat. 1.

Art Institute of Chicago, "John Marin's Watercolors: A Medium for Modernism," Jan. 19-Apr. 17, 2011, pp. 44-45, 52, 89-90, fig. 26, pl. 19; traveled to the High Museum, Atlanta, June 26-Sept. 11, 2011.
provenance_text: Alfred Stieglitz (1864–1946), New York; Stieglitz Estate (Georgia O'Keeffe (1887–1986), executor); given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1956.
copyright_notice: © 2018 Estate of John Marin / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York
